title: How to Write a Speech if You're Third Speaker

steps.title: Create a list of key points from your first and second speaker so that you have them ready when it comes time to give your closing summary.
steps.content: Create a list of key points from your first and second speaker so that you have them ready when it comes time to give your closing summary. If you cannot prepare this in advance, take notes while the first and second speakers are talking. Make a list of the main arguments of first and second speakers on your team. Use the notes to rebut arguments of the opposing side. Throughout the debate, note down key clashes and the main arguments of the opposing side. [1] X Research source State the clashes and explain/analyze why your side has won in each clash.

steps.title: Draft a persuasive closing statement.
steps.content: Draft a persuasive closing statement. You can make changes to your statement throughout the debate, if need be, after taking notes on your challenger's arguments. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Rebut the opposition's arguments.
steps.content: Rebut the opposition's arguments. While it may seem redundant with some of the work the first or second speaker has done, this is an opportunity for a new angle to be presented (e.g. impact on individual vs. impact on society). Take notes while you listen to the first speakers on the opposing side so that you can appropriately rebut key points they've made. [3] X Research source

steps.title: Defend your affirmative arguments with supporting examples.
steps.content: Defend your affirmative arguments with supporting examples. Prepare different cases than your first and second speaker so that you are not just repeating previous examples.

steps.title: Provide a concise summary of your case by listing arguments from your first and second speaker and any strong, supporting examples they may have used.
steps.content: Provide a concise summary of your case by listing arguments from your first and second speaker and any strong, supporting examples they may have used. [4] X Research source

steps.title: End your speech with your closing statement.
steps.content: End your speech with your closing statement. [5] X Research source

steps.title: Rebut the proposition's arguments by using a new and different angle for your argument.
steps.content: Rebut the proposition's arguments by using a new and different angle for your argument. You should complement the work the first and second speakers have done, while keeping the argument fresh. You do not want your argument to get stale.

steps.title: Defend negative arguments by using appropriate supporting examples.
steps.content: Defend negative arguments by using appropriate supporting examples. [6] X Research source It is important to note that if you are a third speaker on an opposing team, you are not creating a constructive argument. Presenting a new argument at this time would not allow the proposing team to rebut. The arguments you are defending are arguments that have already been made by your first and second speakers.
